Name: DIMETHYL PHTHALATE
Description: Dimethyl phthalate is a phthalate ester, a diester and a methyl ester.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Webber MD et al; J Environ Qual 23: 1019-26 (1994) (2) MacKintosh CE et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 2011-20 (2004) (3) Cai QY et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 77: 411-8 (2006)
plant_concentrations.Value: Dimethyl phthalate was not detected in corn grain, carrot or cabbage samples taken Sept to Nov 1987 from St David Coal Refuse Pile Reclamation site in Illinois(1). Dimethyl phthalate was found in aquatic organisms June to Sept 1999 from False Harbor, Vancouver, British Columbia; green algae (Enteromorpha intestinalis) 1.86 ng/g lipid and brown algae (Nereocysitis luetkeana, Fucus gardneri) 1.27 ng/g lipid(2). Dimethyl phthalate was detected at 0.01-0.08 mg/kg dry weight in water spinach (Ipomoea aquatica) grown under different conditions on sludge from waste water treatment plants in China(3).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Mo CH et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 56: 181-9 (2009)

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Wofford HW et al; Ecotox Environ Safety 5: 202-10 (1981) (2) Barrows ME et al; pp. 379-92 in Dyn Exposure Hazard Assess. Ann Arbor,MI: Ann Arbor Science (1980) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994) (4) Giam CS et al; The Handbook of Environmental Chemistry; Anthropogenic Substances. Germany: Springer-Verlag Berlin 3: 67-142 (1984) (5) Cai QY et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 77: 411-8 (2006)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: The mean BCF of dimethyl phthalate in sheepshead minnows was 5.4, after 24 hr(1). Bluegill sunfish showed a bioconcentration factor of 57(2) which may be elevated because only carbon-14 was measured in the experiment and metabolites may be included in the measurement of the parent compound(SRC). The depuration half-life was between 1 and 2 days(2). According to a classification scheme(3), these measured BCFs suggest that bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low to moderate(SRC). The mean BCF of dimethyl phthalate in brown shrimp was 4.7, after 24 hr(1). Bioaccumulation factors of 3.1 and 6.3 were measured in shrimp (Peneaus aztecus) following 1 day of exposure(4). BCFs of 0.14-0.57 were reported for dimethyl phthalate in water spinach (Ipomoea aquatica) grown under different conditions on sludge from waste water treatment plants in China(5).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Sugatt RH et al; Appl Environ Microbiol 47: 601-6 (1984) (2) Tabak HH et al; J Water Pollut Control Fed 531: 1503-18 (1981) (3) Horowitz A et al; Dev Ind Microbiol 23: 435-44 (1982) (4) Petrasek AC et al; J Water Pollut Control Fed 55: 1286-96 (1983) (5) USEPA; Treatability Manual; pp.I6.1-1 toI6.1-6 USEPA-600/2-82-001a (1981) (6) Barth EF, Branch RL; Biodegradation and treatability of specific pollutants. Cincinnati,OH: USEPA, Off Res Devel. USEPA-600/2-84-061 (NITS PB84159904) (1984) (11) Wang J et al; Environ Int 22: 737-41 (1996) (12) Staples CA et al; Chemosphere 35: 667-749 (1997)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: After a 2.7 day lag, dimethyl phthalate was degraded in a shake-flask biodegradation test utilizing a soil/sewage inoculum with a half-life of 1.9 days(1). After 28 days, >99% of the dimethyl phthalate had disappeared and 86% mineralization had occurred(1). Dimethyl phthalate was completely degraded within 7 days in a static flask screening test with a wastewater inoculum(2). In two operating plants, 88 and 58% of the dimethyl phthalate was mineralized by the digested municipal sludge(3). In waste water treatment plants, essentially 100% removal resulting from biodegradation was reported(4-6). In a survey of publicly owned treatment works, an average removal of 97% was attributed to biodegradation(7). Dimethyl phthalate, present at 100 mg/L, reached 93% of its theoretical BOD in 4 weeks using an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L in the Japanese MITI test(8). In activated sludge die-away tests and in a semi-continuous activated sludge test >90% and >81.0% degradation, respectively, was achieved in 1 day(9). Dimethyl phthalate removal of >96 to >99% was observed at the Cedar Creek Wastewater Reclamation - Recharge Facilities, Nassau County, NY(10). Dimethyl phthalate, at a starting concentration of 10-100 mg/L, was biodegraded 90% in 3 days and 100% in 5 days, and had a half-life of 21 hours in acclimated activated sludge from a coke plant waste water treatment system(11). Aerobic degradation studies indicated primary degradation for the lower molecular weight phthalate esters (including dimethyl phthalate) occurred rapidly, typically exceeding 90% degradation within a week, even if unacclimated inocula were used(12).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Williams GR, Dale R; Int Biodeter Bull 19: 37-8 (1983) (2) Osipoff RJ et al; Proc Ind Waste Conf 35: 17-23 (1981) (3) Wolverton BC, McDonald-McCaleb RC; J Mis Acad Sci 31: 79-89 (1986) (4) Russell DJ et al; J Environ Sci Health A 20: 927-41 (1985) (5) Kincannon DF, Lin YS; Proc Ind Waste Conf 40: 607-19 (1985)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Microorganisms isolated from soil are capable of utilizing dimethyl phthalate(1). Biodegradation studies using unacclimated soil cultures indicated that dimethyl phthalate was readily biodegradable(2). Dimethyl phthalate, present at 1032.6 ug/L, was removed 66% in a microbial filter system after 24 hours; 81% removal was observed after 24 hours in a microbial filter system supporting the growth of the common reed(3). In soil-water systems, dimethyl phthalate was completely degraded after 72 hours in leachate sprayed soil; 15% of the 1 hour aqueous dimethyl phthalate concentration remained after 120 hours incubation in Broome County, NY soil(4). In biological soil reactor studies, removal half-lives of 15, 51, 19.1, 72.2 and 123.5 days were measured for dimethyl phthalate in derby soil with DAF sludge, derby soil with 66 g/kg slop oil sludge, Masham soil with 33 g/kg slop oil sludge, 86 g/kg wood preserving sludge and 172 g/kg wood preserving sludge, respectively(5).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Taylor BF et al; Appl Environ Micorbiol 42: 590-5 (1981) (2) Walker WW et al; Chemosphere 13: 1283-94 (1984) (3) Ritsema R et al; Chemosphere 18: 2161-75 (1989) (4) Hattori Y et al; Pollut Control Cent Osaka Prefect Mizu Shori Gijutsu 16: 951-4 (1975) (5) Capel PD, Larson SJ; Chemosphere 30: 1097-1107 (1995)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Microorganisms isolated from natural waters are capable of utilizing dimethyl phthalate(1). Dimethyl phthalate was biodegraded 50% in 1-5 days and complete disappearance was obtained in 2-13 days in sediment-water systems obtained from 6 geographically different estuarine and freshwater sites bordering on the Gulf of Mexico(2). Biodegradation in the water alone proceeded somewhat slower (half-life 2-12 days, complete disappearance in 2-17 days) with rapid degradation occurring after a lag period that varied from site to site(2). Complete loss of dimethyl phthalate was observed within 3 days in Rhine river water at 20 °C; at 4 °C, biodegradation was negligible(3). In a river die-away test using Ogawa River water (Japan), 100% degradation occurred in 8-11 days in two samples(4). Degradation in ocean water was much slower with 20 and 32% degradation occurring in 2 weeks in ocean water and ocean water near a coastal factory, respectively(4). In natural waters, the biodegradation half-life of dimethyl phthalate is estimated as 1 day(5).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Madsen T et al; Chemosphere 31: 4243-58 (1995) (2) Shelton DR, Tiedje JM; Development of Tests for Determining Anaerobic Biodegradation Potential EPA 560/5-81-013 (NTIS PB84-166495) East Lansing, MI, Michigan State Univ, Dept Crop Soil Sci (1981) (3) O'Connor OA et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 8: 569-76 (1989) (4) Ziogou K et al; Water Res 23: 743-8 (1989) (5) Battersby NS, Wilson V; Appl Environ Microbiol 55: 433-9 (1989) (6) Shelton DR et al; Environ Sci Technol 18: 93-7 (1984) (7) Wang J et al; Chemosphere 41: 1245-8 (2000) (8) Kleerebezem R et al; Biodegradation 10: 63-73 (1999) (9) Jianlong W et al; Chemosphere 41: 1245-8 (2000) (10) Capel PD, Larson SJ; Chemosphere 30: 1097-07 (1995)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ANAEROBIC: In an anaerobic gas production test, dimethyl phthalate reached 0-30% and 30-75% of its theoretical mineralization after 56 days incubation in anaerobic sewage sludge and a freshwater swamp, respectively; 0-30% of its theoretical mineralization was reached after 96 days in marine sediment under anaerobic conditions(1). Following a lag period of 1 week, dimethyl phthalate reached 88 and 58% of its theoretical methane production after 8 weeks incubation in 10% Adrian and Jackson sewage sludge, respectively(2). In anaerobic bioassays, dimethyl phthalate, at a concentration of 20 mg/L, achieved 75-100% of its theoretical methane production over an extended incubation period of 50-100 days; at higher concentrations, 100-200 mg/L, dimethyl phthalate achieved 25-50% of its theoretical methane production over the same time period(3). During batch anaerobic digestion of sewage sludge, dimethyl phthalate, at 0.5-10 mg/L, had a half-life of 78 hours(4). Under methanogenic conditions, dimethyl phthalate reached 41% of its theoretical gas production following a lag period of 16 days in an anaerobic digesting sludge from the UK(5). Dimethyl phthalate was completely degraded when digested anaerobically in undiluted and 10% municipal sludge in 1 and 10 days, respectively, with 82% mineralization occurring in the 10% sludge(6). Dimethyl phthalate, present at 10 mg/L, reached 78% of its theoretical methane production in 4 days with a half-life of 23.9 hours(7). Dimethyl phthalate, at a concentration of 1.5 mM, had anaerobic half-lives of 16, 38 and 17 days in starch processing, paper mill and sewage sludge, respectively(8). Dimethyl phthalate was degraded >90% in 4 days and had a calculated half-life of 23.9 hours(9). In natural waters, the biodegradation half-life of dimethyl phthalate is estimated as 4 days(10).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) McFall JA et al; Chemosphere 14: 1561-9 (1985) (2) Rasmussen T et al; Chemosphere 27: 2123-5 (1993) (3) Lin ZP et al; Environ Sci Technol 37: 2100-8 (2003) (4) Devault DS; Arch Environ Cont Toxicol 14: 587-94 (1985) (5) Camanzo J et al; J Great Lakes Res 13: 296-309 (1987) (6) Albert LA; Adv Environ Sci Technol 23: 541-77 (1990)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: A mean dimethyl phthalate concentration of 8.4 ng/g wet weight was detected in oysters collected from the mouth of the Inner Harbor Navigation Canal, Lake Pontchartrain, LA in May to June 1980; clams collected from the mouth of the Rigolets, Lake Pontchartrain, LA during the same time period contained a mean dimethyl phthalate concentration of 44 ng/g wet weight(1). Dimethyl phthalate was found in Mytilus edulis (blue mussels) taken near Holbek, Denmark on Sept 5 and Oct 1, 1991 at 4.5 and 3.1% of volatile components and not detected Nov 5, 1991(2). Three seaperch (Embiotoea lateralis) taken from False Creek, Vancouver, Canada contained 0.1-1.0 ppb of dimethyl phthalate(3). Dimethyl phthalate was analyzed for but not found in edible fish from Wisconsin lakes and rivers(4), and 13 tributaries and Grand Travarse Bay, Lake Michigan(5). Machrobranchium sp, Cynoscium arenarius, and Callenectus sp taken from Blanco River, Veracruz, Mexico contained dimethyl phthalate at 382.0, 4.03, and 488.77 ug/g of extractable lipid, respectively(6).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) MacKintosh CE et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 2011-20 (2004)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Aquatic organisms collected June to Sept 1999 from False Harbor, Vancouver, British Columbia were analyzed for concentrations of dimethyl phthalate(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Peterson JC, Freeman DH; Int J Environ Analyt Chem 18: 237-52 (1984) (2) Hochreiter JJ Jr; Chemical-quality reconnaissance of the water and surficial bed material in the Delaware River Estuary and adjacent New Jersey tributaries, 1980-81. USGS/WRI/NTIS 82-36 (1982) (3) Lopes TJ, Furlong ET; Environ Sci Technol 20: 727-37 (2001) (4) Schwarzbauer J et al; Org Geochem 31: 1713-31 (2000) (5) Wang H et al; Chemosphere 50: 557-62 (2003) (6) McFall JA et al; Chemosphere 14: 1561-9 (1985) (7) Lin ZP et al; Environ Sci Technol 37: 2100-8 (2003) (8) Preston MR, Al-Omran LA; Mar Pollut Bull 17: 548-53 (1986) (9) Preston MR, Al-Omran LA; Environ Pollut 62: 183-93 (1989) (10) Tan GH; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 54: 171-6 (1995)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Dimethyl phthalate was detected, not quantified, at 5 of 12 sites in Chester River, downstream from plasticizer manufacturer, near where it joins Chesapeake Bay(1). A trace of dimethyl phthalate was detected in a tributary of Delaware River (Raccoon Creek) at Bridgeport, NJ in surficial bed material(2). Sediment samples from the Inner Harbor Navigation Canal and the Chef Menteur Pass, Lake Pontchartrain, LA contained 0.2 and 2.0 ng/g dry weight dimethyl phthalate, respectively(3). Dimethyl phthalate was detected in 0.6% of 521 sites samples Aug 1992 to Sept 1995 in 20 major river basins across the US with a maximum concentration of 120 ug/kg dry weight(4). Dimethyl phthalate was found in surface sediment samples at 4 sites in False Creek in Vancouver, Canada(5). A sediment sample collected from the River Mersey, UK contained 140 ng/g dimethyl phthalate(6). Dimethyl phthalate was detected in surface sediment samples collected from Speke and Runcorn in the River Mersey estuary, UK in Oct 1986 at 0.130 and 0.150 ug/g dry weight, respectively(7). Sediment samples collected from Klang River water, Malaysia between Jan 1992 to Feb 1993 contained dimethyl phthalate at average concentrations ranging from not detected to 10.1 ng/g dry weight(8). Dimethyl phthalate was not found in sediment samples taken from 12 sites in 2000 from Taihu Lake China(9). Dimethyl phthalate was detected in sediment in 7 of 7 sites located in the German Bight area(10).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Webber MD et al; J Environ Qual 23: 1019-26 (1994) (2) Webber MD, Wang C; Can J Soil Sci 75: 513-24 (1995) (3) Li XH et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 77: 252-9 (2006) (4) Liu H et al; Chemosphere 78: 382-388 (2010)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Dimethyl phthalate was not detected in soil samples taken Sept to Nov 1987 from St David Coal Refuse Pile Reclamation site in Illinois(1). Dimethyl phthalate was detected not in 4 of 10 (detection limit of 0.03 mg/kg dry weight) and detected, not quantified, in 6 of 10 (<0.03 mg/kg dry weight) selected Canadian soils(2). Dimethyl phthalate concentrations were not detected to 0.067 mg/kg dry weight in 30 soil samples from Beijing, China(3). Soil samples collected from 26 sites in the JiangHan plain, China contained dimethyl phthalate at not detected (detection limit not reported) to 238.1 ng/g; samples were collected June 2007 and Jan 2008(4).

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Osipoff RJ et al; Proc Ind Waste Conf 35: 17-23 (1981) (2) Banerjee P et al; Chemosphere 14: 1057-67 (1985) (3) Zurmuehl T et al; J Contam Hydrol 8: 111-33 (1991) (4) Thomsen M et al; Chemosphere 38: 2613-24 (1999) (5) Lu C; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 83:168-73 (2009) (6) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983) (7) Zarth MOF et al; Vom Wasser 63: 281-97 (1984) (8) Sutton PA, Barker JF; Ground Water 23: 10-6 (1985) (9) Ritsema R et al; Chemosphere 18: 2161-75 (1989) (10) Al-Omran LA, Preston MR; Environ Pollut 46: 177-86 (1987)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Dimethyl phthalate had a Koc of 55 in soil (89% sand, 11% silt/clay, 20% organic carbon) taken from Calumet, MI(1). Koc values ranging from 80 to 360 were calculated for dimethyl phthalate from its low carbon subsurface core sorption isotherms at different depths(2). Dimethyl phthalate had measured log Koc values of 1.88 to 1.89 in Typic Haplaquept type loamy, sandy soil(3). Dimethyl phthalate also had a reported Koc of 200(4) and log Koc value of 2.3(5). According to a classification scheme(6), these Koc values suggest that dimethyl phthalate is expected to have moderate to high mobility in soil(SRC). An average dimethyl phthalate removal of 79% was observed on a 14 m experimental overland flow slope(7). Relative to the average linear groundwater velocity, 18% retardation was calculated for dimethyl phthalate in a natural gradient tracer test using an unconfined sandy aquifer, assuming an organic carbon content of 0.05%(8). A mean sediment log Koc value of >5.2 was calculated from the mean dimethyl phthalate concentration in water and suspended particulate matter from Lake Yssel, The Netherlands(9). Adsorption of dimethyl phthalate is enhanced in the presence of salt: at a dimethyl phthalate concentration of 700 ug/L, 0.9 ug/g was adsorbed on suspended particulates in seawater, 0.6 ug/g was adsorbed on suspended particulates in 50% sea water, and <0.2 ug/g was adsorbed on suspended particulates in distilled water(10).

plant_translocation.References: Zhang, D., Zhou, K., Liu, C., Li, X., Pan, S., & Zhong, L. (2023). Dissipation, uptake, translocation and accumulation of five phthalic acid esters in sediment-Zizania latifolia system. Chemosphere, 315, 137651.
plant_translocation.Value: According to Table S1, DAP, DBP, BBP and DEHP were selected. DIBP could be used as a substitute for DBP due to their similarities, and it was also included. Dimethyl phthalate (DMP) and diethyl phthalate (DEP) were excluded because of their poor recoveries by the proposed method in this study. The chemical structures and physicochemical properties of the five PAEs are shown in Table S2.
